image.altText: A crowd of people stand on the street outside an Optus store

items.synopsis: Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin says the company has not identifed the root cause of the outage affecting millions of Australians, while there is "no indication" it has been caused by a cyber attack. Follow live.

title.children: Optus has not identified cause of major outage, 'will not rest' until services back online

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Communications Minister Michelle Rowland held a press conference a few minutes ago. She was asked about the cause of the outage. Unfortunately, we don't have any answers yet. Here's what Ms Rowland says "My understanding is that this is a fault deep in the core. "The core network basically encompasses everything from routing to electronics. "So it is a fault that is quite fundamental to the network. "But my understanding, having just recently spoken again to the CEO, is that a number of problems have been identified, and that Optus continues to work on this."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Communications minister: Outage due to 'deep fault'

children.content: Communications Minister Michelle Rowland
held a press conference a few minutes ago.
She was asked about the cause of the outage.
Unfortunately, we don't have any answers yet.
Here's what Ms
Rowland says
"My understanding is that this is a fault deep in the core.
"The core network basically encompasses everything from routing to electronics.
"So it is a fault that is quite fundamental to the network.
"But my understanding, having just recently spoken again to the CEO, is that a number of problems have been identified, and that Optus continues to work on this."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ACCAN's CEO Andrew Williams spoke with ABC News Channel. He says it's "legitimate" for Optus's business customers relying on cashless payments to stay closed until the system is back online:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Telco consumer advocate urges Optus customers to record losses from outage

image.altText: A wide shot of a land with soldiers and tanks among destroyed buildings with a ferris wheel in the distance and ocean beyond.

items.synopsis: Israel says its forces are operating deep in Gaza City, adding that Hamas' most senior leader in the enclave is isolated in his bunker. Follow live.

title.children: IDF says troops move into 'the very heart of Gaza' as Israel marks one month since Hamas attacks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends. Yesterday Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu raised the prospect of Israel taking control of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated. "Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't", Eylon Levy, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told Patricia Karvelas on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words. He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza strip would have to be demilitarised. The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said. When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated: "When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time. "We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years." Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel wants to exercise 'ultimate security control' over Gaza after war, government spokesperson says

featuredLink.title: What happens to Gaza when the conflict ends? - ABC listen

children.content: While Israel has been clear about its desire to eliminate Hamas, what remains less clear is who would assume responsibility for the Gaza Strip once the military operation ends.
Yesterday Israeli PM
Benjamin Netanyahu
raised the prospect of Israel taking control
of the administration of the Gaza Strip once Hamas is defeated.
"Clearly Israel is going to have to exercise ultimate security control over the Gaza strip, because we saw what happened when we don't",
Eylon Levy
, spokesperson for the Israeli government, told
Patricia Karvelas
on RN Breakfast when asked to comment on Netanyahu's words.
He said he could not go into detail on what "ultimate security control" would mean, but said the Gaza strip would have to be demilitarised.
The last 20 years since Israel withdrew its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip were a "failed experiment", he said.
When asked by about US officials' comments against an Israeli occupation of Gaza, Levy elaborated:
"When we talk about ultimate security for the Gaza strip, we are not talking about Israeli soldiers necessarily patrolling inside and being there all the time.
"We're going to need mechanisms and safeguards to ensure that the area is not taken over by terrorists the way that it has been over the last 20 years."
Listen to the full interview on ABC RN Breakfast below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Even before the October 7 Hamas attacks, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was in hot water. Anger at him has been boiling for months over his unwavering push to change Israel's judiciary, coupled with a cost-of-living crisis. "Since his re-election to the top job at the end of 2022, Bibi, as he's known to most people here, has created a deep rift inside Israeli society that's gone to heart of the future of this country," Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn writes. "Even in times of political crisis, one thing usually holds Israel together. Security. But this month has been different. "Many people who already believed Bibi had divided the country now hold him responsible for the most shocking breach of Israeli defences in half a century." Read the full analysis by Allyson Horn below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dissatisfaction towards Netanyahu intensifies in Israel

featuredLink.title: 'The real problem is the guy who's our leader': Israelis are furious with PM Benjamin Netanyahu

Anger at him has been boiling for months over his unwavering push to change Israel's judiciary, coupled with a cost-of-living crisis.
"Since his re-election to the top job at the end of 2022, Bibi, as he's known to most people here, has created a deep rift inside Israeli society that's gone to heart of the future of this country,"
Middle East correspondent Allyson Horn
writes.
"Even in times of political crisis, one thing usually holds Israel together. Security. But this month has been different.
"Many people who already believed Bibi had divided the country now hold him responsible for the most shocking breach of Israeli defences in half a century."
Read the full analysis by Allyson Horn below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The number of evacuees leaving the Gaza Strip through Egypt rose on Tuesday local time, a day after the Rafah border crossing was re-opened. At least 500 people, most of them foreigners or dual nationals and their dependents passed through Rafah, the only crossing that does not border Israel, Egyptian security sources said. Evacuations through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah. Egyptian security sources said Egypt was continuing to press for increased aid and fuel into the strip and security for ambulances. Jordan's foreign ministry said 262 Jordanians were evacuated on Tuesday, out of a total of 569 that had been stuck in Gaza following the outbreak of fighting there. Canada said 59 of its citizens, permanent residents and family members were evacuated. Nineteen Gazans needing medical treatment were also allowed through, a medical source said, to join dozens of others who are being treated in Egyptian hospitals. Other countries with citizens cleared to leave on Tuesday included Romania, Germany, Moldova, Ukraine, the Philippines and France, according to the Gaza border authority. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza evacuations through Rafah crossing accelerate after re-opening

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas has faced court for its first hearing in action brought by Australia's consumer watchdog over the airline's decision to sell thousands of "ghost flights" - tickets for cancelled flights. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) launched legal action against the airline in August, accusing Qantas of failing to address accusations it sold thousands of tickets for cancelled flights between May and July 2022. The watchdog alleges Qantas engaged in false, misleading, or deceptive conduct by advertising and selling tickets for more than 8000 "ghost flights" which had already been cancelled. It alleges that the airline kept selling tickets on its website for an average of more than two weeks, and in some cases for up to 47 days, after the cancellation of the flights. The consumer watchdog also alleges that for more than 10,000 flights scheduled to depart in May to July 2022, Qantas did not notify existing ticketholders that their flights had been cancelled for an average of about 18 days, and in some cases for up to 48 days. Qantas has denied breaking consumer laws, saying while it "fully accepts it let customers down during the post-COVID restart, including with high cancellation rates" and "while mistakes were made, the ACCC's legal case ignores the realities of the aviation industry — airlines can't guarantee specific flight times". The court heard the parties will aim to agree on the facts of the case before holding a hearing on the question of Qantas' liability next year. At a brief case management hearing in Melbourne on Wednesday, it was agreed they will return to the court on February 28 next year. The ACCC is seeking orders in the Federal Court for the alleged misconduct, including penalties, injunctions, declarations, and costs. The controversy has seen Qantas's share price take a hit in recent months and at its annual general meeting last week shareholders delivered a significant protest vote against the board's plan for executive pay, with 83 per cent of shareholders voting against management plans.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Court date set for ACCC case against Qantas over 'ghost flights'

children.content: Qantas has faced court for its first hearing in action brought by Australia's consumer watchdog over the airline's decision to sell thousands of "ghost flights" - tickets for cancelled flights.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC)
launched legal action against the airline in August
, accusing Qantas of failing to address accusations it sold thousands of tickets for cancelled flights between May and July 2022.

The watchdog alleges Qantas engaged in false, misleading, or deceptive conduct by advertising and selling tickets for more than 8000 "ghost flights" which had already been cancelled. It alleges that the airline kept selling tickets on its website for an average of more than two weeks, and in some cases for up to 47 days, after the cancellation of the flights.

The consumer watchdog also alleges that for more than 10,000 flights scheduled to depart in May to July 2022, Qantas did not notify existing ticketholders that their flights had been cancelled for an average of about 18 days, and in some cases for up to 48 days.
The ACCC alleges Qantas engaged in false, misleading, or deceptive conduct.
(ABC News: John Gunn)
Qantas has denied breaking consumer laws

, saying while it "fully accepts it let customers down during the post-COVID restart, including with high cancellation rates" and "while mistakes were made, the ACCC's legal case ignores the realities of the aviation industry — airlines can't guarantee specific flight times".
The court heard the parties will aim to agree on the facts of the case before holding a hearing on the question of Qantas' liability next year.
At a brief case management hearing in Melbourne on Wednesday, it was agreed they will return to the court on February 28 next year.
The ACCC is seeking orders in the Federal Court for the alleged misconduct, including penalties, injunctions, declarations, and costs.
The controversy has seen Qantas's share price take a hit in recent months and
at its annual general meeting last week shareholders delivered a significant protest vote against the board's plan for executive pay,
with 83 per cent of shareholders voting against management plans.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In further signs that the market, if not all economists, believe the RBA is now done hiking interest rates after yesterday's move, tech stocks, industrials, real estate, financials and consumer cyclical retailers are all gaining ground. However, the big mining (-1.6%) and energy (-1.2%) sectors are down, which has lowered gains for the major indices. The ASX 200 index is only up 2 points at 6,979 points. With gold miners also on the nose today, it was a rough arrival on the ASX for Newmont Corporation, which has just completed the takeover of Australia's Newcrest, and now has an Australian listing. Biggest gains: James Hardie Industries +11% to $45.81 Weebit Nano +5.3% to $4.35 Block +2.8% to $79.02 Sayona Mining +2.5% to $0.082 Magellan Financial Group +2.5% to $7.11 Biggest losses: Coronado Global Resources -4.2% to $1.6425 Domain Holdings -4.2% to $3.515 Whitehaven Coal -4.1% to $6.52 Bellevue Gold -3.9% to $1.36 Newmont Corporation -3.4% to $56.65
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX ekes out modest gains in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While a lot of local rates analysts are keeping open the prospect of another rate hike, and NAB's economics team is even expecting one in February, financial markets are doubtful. Bloomberg data show financial markets pricing in no chance of a rate hike next month and about a 34% chance of a rate hike in February. The market is pricing in a cash rate below the current 4.35% target by November next year. The Australian dollar has fallen half a cent from around 64.8 US cents just ahead of yesterday's rates announcement to 64.3 this morning. Saxo Asia-Pacific market strategist Charu Chanana says many traders are of the view that the RBA is now done with rate rises, as are most other developed economy central banks. "What is clear from (yesterday's) meeting is that the RBA is done — the market will look to price in rate cuts now for next year. "Any softening in data will push the rate cut pricing to H1 [first half] or even Q1 [first quarter] next year. "As such, AUD [Australian dollar] has seen the end of gains driven by the RBA pricing. From here on, China's recovery will become the key driver for AUD once again, along with the global risk sentiment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar falls as analyst says it's 'clear that the RBA is done'

children.content: While a lot of local rates analysts are keeping open the prospect of another rate hike, and NAB's economics team is even expecting one in February, financial markets are doubtful.
Bloomberg data show financial markets pricing in
no chance of a rate hike next month and about a 34% chance of a rate hike in February
The market is pricing in a cash rate below the current 4.35% target by November next year.
The
Australian dollar has fallen half a cent from around 64.8 US cents just ahead of yesterday's rates announcement to 64.3
this morning.
Saxo Asia-Pacific market strategist Charu Chanana
says many traders are of the view that the RBA is now done with rate rises, as are most other developed economy central banks.
"What is clear from (yesterday's) meeting is that the RBA is done — the market will look to price in rate cuts now for next year.
"Any softening in data will push the rate cut pricing to H1 [first half] or even Q1 [first quarter] next year.

"As such, AUD [Australian dollar] has seen the end of gains driven by the RBA pricing. From here on, China's recovery will become the key driver for AUD once again, along with the global risk sentiment."
